newsitem.title: BOSNIA: UNHCR says Sarajevo denies housing to minorities.
newsitem.headline: UNHCR says Sarajevo denies housing to minorities.

text.p: The U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) on Tuesday accused Bosnian Moslem authorities in Sarajevo of disriminating against Serbs and Croats trying to return to flats it had repaired.
The Sarajevo canton had permitted only Moslem families to move into flats repaired by the UNHCR at a cost of 6.8 million German marks ($4 million), a UNHCR spokesman told a news conference.

"For months now the cantonal minister of housing has failed to present 29 families with the keys to their newly-renovated apartments despite sufficient evidence of their tenancy rights," said UNHCR spokesman Kris Janowski.
"Virtually all those concerned are Serbs and Croats which gives us cause to believe that they are being discriminated against because of their ethnicity," he said.
Munib Buljina, minister for housing in the Sarajevo canton, was unavailable for comment.

Janowski said the refusal by Sarajevo authorities to permit minorities to return to their homes threatened "Sarajevo's image as a multi-ethnic city" and violated the spirit of the UNHCR housing project.
The UNHCR has repeatedly tried to persuade the cantonal authority "to reverse its position but so far to no avail", he said.

Despite reports of abuses in Sarajevo, Janowski said the city was still far more tolerant towards ethnic minorities than other towns, including Serb-controlled Banja Luka or Croat-controlled western Mostar.
Sarajevo was once known for its mixed population but after the Bosnian conflict and a 43-month long Serb siege, the city is predominantly Moslem.
